docs.snippet: "I feel kind of sorry for a grown-up man to have to use 10-year-olds as a platform for getting attention," Public School 22's tearful chorus master said....
docs.lead_paragraph: When the wheels were up on the two Continental Airlines flights from Los Angeles carrying the 64 Staten Island public school students home from their star turn singing the finale at the Academy Awards, the chorus squirmed in their seats with triumphant joy. But on Tuesday evening, they landed with a thump.
docs.abstract: "I feel kind of sorry for a grown-up man to have to use 10-year-olds as a platform for getting attention," Public School 22's tearful chorus master said.

headline.main: For P.S. 22 Chorus, There's No Place Like Home

docs.snippet: Tom Hooper, winner of the best director Oscar for "The King's Speech," gave a shout-out to his mother during his acceptance speech. She now corrects the record....
docs.lead_paragraph: It was the aphorism heard round the world. "The moral of the story is, listen to your mother," Tom Hooper said, accepting his Oscar for best director Sunday night, after recounting how his Australian-born mum led him to the material that became "The King's Speech." The phrase instantly lit up Twitter and became fodder for guilt-inducing (or -induced) messages between parents and children. In a night notable mostly for its flubs, it was one of the few memorable lines.
docs.abstract: Tom Hooper, winner of the best director Oscar for "The King's Speech," gave a shout-out to his mother during his acceptance speech. She now corrects the record.

headline.main: A Chat With the Mother Who Knows Best

docs.snippet: The documentary "Wretches & Jabberers" will be shown in 40 cities....
docs.lead_paragraph: A little documentary about autism -- playing in a multiplex? AMC, one of the largest movie theater chains in North America, plans to announce on Thursday that it will give a film about two men with autism, "Wretches & Jabberers," a national theatrical run. The feature documentary, directed by Gerardine Wurzburg (who won an Oscar in 1992 for the short "Educating Peter," about a boy with Down syndrome), will have a one-week run starting April 1 at the AMC Empire 25 in Manhattan.
docs.abstract: The documentary "Wretches & Jabberers" will be shown in 40 cities.

headline.main: AMC to Give Autism Film National Exposure

docs.snippet: The Oscars got lots of attention in social media, not all of it complimentary....
docs.lead_paragraph: In search of a younger audience, the producers of Sunday evening's broadcast of the 83rd Academy Awards pulled out all the stops to engage viewers on social media, even having one of their own co-hosts live-tweet during the ceremony.
docs.abstract: The Oscars got lots of attention in social media, not all of it complimentary.

headline.main: Oscars Online: 'No' to James Franco, 'Yes' to Bob Hope

docs.snippet: On Tuesday night's semifinal round show, which featured the season's top 12 male contestants, audition-round favorites were exposed as scammers, charlatans and fools. This season's conceit, in which the show appeared to be focusing on skilled cont...
docs.lead_paragraph: There is Jacob Lusk, and then there is "American Idol." That they overlap, at least for now, is something of a miracle.
docs.abstract: On Tuesday night's semifinal round show, which featured the season's top 12 male contestants, audition-round favorites were exposed as scammers, charlatans and fools. This season's conceit, in which the show appeared to be focusing on skilled contestants over punchline-ready singers, felt like a bait-and-switch. Just last week, they were singers; now, they were set up to be collateral damage.

docs.snippet: What's not to love about a chorus of adorable Staten Island schoolchildren rounding out the Oscars with a rousing rendition of ''Over the Rainbow''?     Plenty, if you're a certain curmudgeonly morning television commentator. On MSNBC's ''Morning ...
docs.lead_paragraph: What's not to love about a chorus of adorable Staten Island schoolchildren rounding out the Oscars with a rousing rendition of ''Over the Rainbow''? Plenty, if you're a certain curmudgeonly morning television commentator. On MSNBC's ''Morning Joe'' on Tuesday, Andy Cohen, Bravo's senior vice president of original programming and development, smilingly delivered a withering critique of the T-shirted fifth graders from Public School 22 who swayed and head-tilted their way into a nation's hearts Sunday night.
docs.abstract: City Room blog on unexpected criticism of rendition of Over the Rainbow performed at the end of the Oscars ceremony by the schoolchildren of PS22 from Staten Island (M)

headline.main: For City's Oscar Singers, a Sharp Critic

docs.snippet: The Oscars telecast has been almost universally panned, with many scapegoats to go around, but so far only man has blamed the schoolchildren....
docs.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES - Not that there aren't plenty of Oscar scapegoats to go around - James Franco, the writers, the Internet - but so far only one man has blamed the schoolchildren. As our sister blog City Room points out, on "Morning Joe" today, Andy Cohen, the Bravo network vice president, said the P.S. 22 fifth-grade choir was the worst thing about the show.
docs.abstract: The Oscars telecast has been almost universally panned, with many scapegoats to go around, but so far only man has blamed the schoolchildren.

headline.main: A Bravo Pan for Those Singing Schoolkids
